column9: C1. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
column10: C2. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
column11: C3. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
column12: C4. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
column13: C5. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach.
column14: C6. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
column15: C7. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
column16: C8. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts.
column17: C9. Wind power has its downsides â€” it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.
column18: C10. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
column19: C11. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
column20: C12. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
column21: C13. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
column22: C14. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
column23: C15. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
column24: C16. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
column25: C17. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
column26: C18. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
column27: C19. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
column28: C20. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
column29: C21. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
column30: C22.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
column31: C23. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
column32: C24. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
column33: C25. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
column34: C26. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
column35: C27. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies.
column36: C28. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
column37: C29. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
column38: C30. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
column39: C31. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
column40: C32. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
column41: C33. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
column42: C34. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
column43: C35. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
column44: C36. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
column45: C37. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
column46: C38. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
column47: C39. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
column48: C40. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
column49: C41. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
column50: C42. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
column51: C43. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
column52: C44. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
column53: C45. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
